content: The Northern lights over Tromso in northern Norway
- Viking Age, in which Scandinavians go on plundering expeditions abroad. Some Norwegians settle at their destinations, including Scotland and Greenland.
- Norway unified into one kingdom.
- Christianity adopted.
- Norway becomes a dependency of Denmark.
- Union with Sweden.
- Norwegian parliament, the Storting, proclaims independence from Sweden. Norwegian people endorse decision in plebiscite. Prince Carl of Denmark becomes King.
- Universal suffrage for women introduced. Norwegian women begin to play greater role in politics.
- Norway, Sweden and Denmark agree to remain neutral during World War One.
- Norway joins the League of Nations.

- Norway suffers considerably as a result of the world economic depression. Trade, shipping and banks all post heavy losses. The value of the krone falls. Unemployment becomes severe and lasts until the beginning of World War Two.
- Norway declares its neutrality at the outbreak of war, but this position becomes increasingly difficult to maintain.
- German forces invade Norway in April, attacking important ports. fighting lasts for two months.
The Royal Family and the government flee to Britain in June. A government-in-exile is set up in London. Vidkun Quisling proclaims himself head of government in Norway.
- Quisling introduces martial law due to widespread resistance and acts of sabotage by the Norwegian people.
- German forces in Norway surrender in May. The King returns to Norway in June. Quisling is tried and executed for treason. Norway becomes a charter member of the United Nations.
- Reconstruction begins, with Norway's gross national product reaching pre-war levels within three years.
- Norway joins the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (Nato).
- Norway becomes founder member of the European Free Trade Association (Efta).
- The Storting, Norway's parliament, votes 136 to 13 to renew a previous Norwegian application to join the EEC.
- Oil and gas deposits are discovered in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea.
- Exploitation of oil and gas deposits begins. By the early 1980s they constitute nearly one-third of Norway's annual export earnings.
- Norwegian voters reject the Labour government's recommendation on EEC membership by a margin of 6%. The government resigns.
- Norway signs a free trade agreement with the EEC.
- International Whaling Commission imposes moratorium on whaling. Norway registers objections.
- King Olaf V dies. He is succeeded by his son, Harald V.
- Norway brokers peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation, which lead to the Oslo accords.
Norway resumes commercial whaling despite international moratorium.
- Norwegians reject membership of the European Union in a referendum for a second time, by a margin of about 5%.
- Norway begins mediation between the government of Sri Lanka and Tamil separatists.

March - Conservative government of Kjell Magne Bondevik resigns over question of how Norway should generate its power. He is succeeded by Labour leader Jens Stoltenberg who favours gas-powered generating plants, despite Norway's strict environmental laws.
January - Tens of thousands protest in Oslo against the murder of a black teenager for which three neo-Nazi youths are subsequently jailed.

Environmentalists angered by decision to lift ban on export of whale meat and blubber. Controversy deepens when government orders cull of grey wolves, an endangered species in Europe, which it accuses of causing serious damage to livestock.
September - Labour government of Jens Stoltenberg suffers heavy defeat in general election in which no single party wins enough votes to form a majority government.
October - Conservatives, Christian People's Party and Liberals agree to form coalition government with support from far-right Progress Party and with Kjell Magne Bondevik as prime minister.
May - Discovery of high levels of chemicals in whale meat leads to pregnant women being warned not to eat it.
December - Plans to explore for oil and gas in the Barents Sea spark criticism from environmentalists and fishing industry.
June - Government intervenes to end week-long strike by oil workers seeking better pension rights and job security after employers threaten lock-out.
September - PM Bondevik loses general election to centre-left alliance led by Labour Party's Jens Stoltenberg, which wins more than half of seats in parliament.

October - Two Norwegian fisheries inspectors are released having been held for five days against their will on board a Russian trawler which fled while they were inspecting it for suspected illegal activity.
February - Constitution amended to abolish bicameral division of parliament after next elections.
September - Centre-left coalition of PM Jens Stoltenberg narrowly wins re-election in parliamentary elections.
September - China warns that Norwegian Nobel committee's decision to award Nobel Peace Prize to jailed Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo will harm relations between Norway and China.
July - Extreme right-winger Anders Behring Breivik carries out a bomb attack and mass shooting, killing more than 70 people in the worst massacre in Norway's modern history.
July - The government uses emergency powers to force offshore oil and gas workers back to work after a 16-day strike over pensions.
August - A Norwegian court finds mass killer Anders Behring Breivik sane and sentences him to 21 years in jail.
January - Norway and the EU reach a new agreement on fishing quotas.
September - Parliamentary elections. Centre-right bloc led by Erna Solberg's Conservative party wins.
May - Major General Kristin Lund from Norway becomes the first woman to command a UN peacekeeping force.
January - The Lutheran Church - to which three-quarters of Norwegians belong - adopts a new liturgy allowing gay couples to marry in church weddings.
September - Erna Solberg claims a new mandate as prime minister following elections.
September - Jonas Gahr Store's centre-left Labour Party forms minority coalition government after winning greatest number of seats in the general election.
